titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Paul Rotha papers LSC.2001
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Library Special Collections staff, 1999; Selina Portera, 2020.

p.date: Online finding aid last updated 2020 February 05.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-04-03 12:05:08 -0700.

did.abstract: Paul Rotha (1907-1984) was a film critic, documentary filmmaker, and movie director. The collection consists of materials related to Rotha's documentary and feature films and Rotha's books on the cinema.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Paul Rotha papers (Collection 2001). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Motley Books, Limited, purchase, 1967. Paul Rotha, purchase, 1980.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Library Special Collections staff, 1999. Container listings for boxes 1-65 and 86-91 compliled by Selina Portera, 2020 based on existing paper inventories.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Paul Rotha was born in London, England on June 3, 1907; a former painter and designer, he became a film critic and wrote a seminal work on cinema history titled, The film till now (1930); began making his own documentary films in association with John Grierson and was a leading figure in the British documentary movement of the 1930s and 1940s; directed three feature films in the 1950-60s; writings include: Documentary film (1935), Rotha on the film (1958), and The innocent eye: A biography of Robert Flaherty (1963); died on March 7, 1984.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of projects, early treatments, narration scripts, technical plans and shooting scripts for Mr. Rotha's documentary and feature films. Also includes manuscript, typescript, and proof copies of Rotha's books on the cinema along with clippings of his periodical writings and review articles. Reviews and articles on Rotha are both loose and in scrapbooks. Includes Rotha's personal diaries as well as correspondence from John Grierson, Eric Knight, and Richard Griffith, among others. There are art works from the 1920s, photographs (mostly location stills), and recording tapes from Rotha's films.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection maintains the exiting order of materials upon transfer to UCLA.

controlaccess.occupation: Motion picture producers and directors -- Archives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Downfall, Emile Zola. The Celebration of 8 Pens, The Madonna of Jermyn Street. As Seen Through a Glass Darkly. "Adieu! N'oubliez-pas la plus Miserable personne du monde." Food.

did.unittitle: 8 Pens, "Menu" commemorating the 50th meeting, illustrations by Rotha

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Young Artist's Exhibition. Mural Paintings at the Tate Gallery. The Paintings of Honoré Daumier, Some Studies in Ballet, The Fourth Centenary of Alrech Durer, Beauty and Fashion in the 'Sixties, Three "Avanced" Artists, Vincent Van Gogh, London Group Retrospective Exhibition, "Largilleére," by Georges Pascal, Toulouse-Latrec, An Artist and Two Painters, Illustrators of the Sixties, Aubrey Beardsley, Old Military Prints, The Pastel Society, Yesterday and To-day, Essays in Rotundity, "New English" Gloom, One Hundred Title-pages, 1500-1800, Amadeo Modigliani, 1885-1920, Unpublished article, La Grauvre Sur Bois Moderne de l'Occident, Orovida, Ridley Art Club, Henry Lamb, Nineteenth-Century Dutch Art, Lady Artists and More Lady Artists, Still More Lady Artists and Some Scottish Painters, A French Modernist, Abstraction, Rural England, Terminology, The Modern English Water-Colour Society, The Seven and Five Society, Eric Gill, The Goupil Salon, Interesting Tendencies, Fashionable, Elegancies, Mr. Edward Wadsworth, Society of Graphic Art, Mr. Walter Richard Sickert, British and French Sculpters, Still Photoraphy, New Interior Decoration, The New Spirit in Russian Theatre.
